provenance.name: City of Westminster Archive
provenance.note: The letter was sold along with the letters of 11 Sept., 23 Sept., 2 Oct. 1800, 10 May, 1801, 10 Jan., 22 Nov. (both parts) 1802, 25 Spril, 6 July, 16 Aug. 1803 by Captain Frederick Butts in about 1906 to W. Graham Robertson, who allowed them to be reproduced in 1926 and bequeathed them in 1948 to Mr. Kerrison Preston, who gave them in 1967 to the Westminster Archives.

exchanged the Buildings of Hercules for the Bed of Neptunes? Bed?Butts revises the sentence, but does not cross out the question mark that concludes the sentence ending in "Neptune." He may have intended for it to read "Neptune's Bed."; Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1544) puts these lines into a verse couplet ("So Virtuous a Woman would ever have fled,/From Hercules' Buildings to Neptunes Bed?") and notes that they were first expressed as prose. Keynes (*Letters*, page 25-26) includes the deleted or overwritten portions of the text here so that "so good a Woman would ever have exchanged Hercules Buildings for Neptune's Bed," precedes the verse couplet.
